content: Do we have IsOpen s ‚Üí IsOpen t ‚Üí IsOpen (s ‚óã t)? Is this even true?
And analogous for the IsClosed version
#mwe? What topology are you talking about?
The product topology

That's a cute question! Here's a MWE for people watching:

import Mathlib.Topology.UniformSpace.Defs
import Mathlib.Topology.Constructions.SumProd

variable {X : Type*} [TopologicalSpace X] {s t : Set (X √ó X)}

lemma IsOpen.compRel (hs : IsOpen s) (ht : IsOpen t) : IsOpen (s ‚óã t) := by
  sorry
The answer should be "yes", just because open boxes compose to open boxes
For open sets, that is. I believe the corresponding result for closed sets is false, but I don't yet have a counterexample at hand

Aaron Liu said:

The product topology

I meant what topology on the original set :-) Is it related to the lattice structure necessary to define ‚óã? Is Yael's version what you're asking?
There's no lattice structure needed to define ‚óã. This is a purely logical definition

Kevin Buzzard said:

Aaron Liu said:

The product topology

I meant what topology on the original set :-) Is it related to the lattice structure necessary to define ‚óã?

‚óã does not need a lattice structure? I'm talking about docs#compRel by the way. And I mean an arbitrary topology, but if that doesn't work I can give more details about where I need this

Kevin Buzzard said:

Is Yael's version what you're asking?

Yes

scoped[FinsetFamily] infixl:74 " ‚óã " => Finset.disjSups

which will teach me to engage with questions without a #mwe :-)

It was in the title
That one is my fault
So ‚óã means two different things in mathlib?
That's why they're scoped!
I think they're both scoped

Anyways here's my #mwe

import Mathlib

variable {X : Type*} [TopologicalSpace X] {s t : Set (X √ó X)}

proof_wanted (hs : IsOpen s) (ht : IsOpen t) : IsOpen (compRel s t)
proof_wanted (hs : IsClosed s) (ht : IsClosed t) : IsClosed (compRel s t)
Repeated IsOpen t and also IsClosed t in hypotheses :sweat_smile:

IlmƒÅrs Cƒ´rulis said:

Repeated IsOpen t and also IsClosed t in hypotheses :sweat_smile:

fixed (edited)
Rough guess (i.e this I don't claim this is true): wouldn't that imply that any topological space is uniformizable?

Anatole Dedecker said:

Rough guess (i.e this I don't claim this is true): wouldn't that imply that any topological space is uniformizable?

Why? Explain your rough reasoning

The unique uniform structure on a compact space is built by declaring that entourages are neighborhood of the diagonal, and then checking axioms. I'm wondering wether your claim would suffice to do so in general (which would mean it's false).
Actually I can't find the construction in Mathlib, only the uniqueness... I could have sworn that we have it...

Let's try it! The cofinite topology on Nat has as neighborhoods of each point atTop ‚äî pure x. That means the neighborhoods of the diagonal are Filter.principal idRel ‚äî Filter.coprod atTop atTop. This is not a uniformity because it is does not satisfy the halving rule.

Anatole Dedecker said:

Actually I can't find the construction in Mathlib, only the uniqueness... I could have sworn that we have it...

The construction is at file#Topology/UniformSpace/OfCompactT2
Aha, thanks!
Okay I don't think that works.
So consider my rough guess to be completely off x)
Anatole, aren't you convinced by my proof above? #Is there code for X? > `IsOpen` and `compRel` @ üí¨
Ah sure, I had missed it :man_facepalming:

Here it is formally:

import Mathlib.Topology.Bases
import Mathlib.Topology.UniformSpace.Defs

open scoped Uniformity

section Topology.UniformSpace.Defs
variable {Œπ : Sort*} {X : Type*} {s‚ÇÅ s‚ÇÇ t‚ÇÅ t‚ÇÇ : Set X}

open Set

lemma prod_compRel_prod_of_inter_nonempty (hst : (s‚ÇÇ ‚à© t‚ÇÅ).Nonempty) :
    s‚ÇÅ √óÀ¢ s‚ÇÇ ‚óã t‚ÇÅ √óÀ¢ t‚ÇÇ = s‚ÇÅ √óÀ¢ t‚ÇÇ := by aesop

lemma prod_compRel_prod_of_disjoint (hst : Disjoint s‚ÇÇ t‚ÇÅ) : s‚ÇÅ √óÀ¢ s‚ÇÇ ‚óã t‚ÇÅ √óÀ¢ t‚ÇÇ = ‚àÖ :=
  eq_empty_of_forall_not_mem fun _ ‚ü®_z, ‚ü®_, hzs‚ü©, hzt, _‚ü© ‚Ü¶ Set.disjoint_left.1 hst hzs hzt

lemma prod_compRel_prod [Decidable (Disjoint s‚ÇÇ t‚ÇÅ)] :
    s‚ÇÅ √óÀ¢ s‚ÇÇ ‚óã t‚ÇÅ √óÀ¢ t‚ÇÇ = if Disjoint s‚ÇÇ t‚ÇÅ then ‚àÖ else s‚ÇÅ √óÀ¢ t‚ÇÇ := by
  split_ifs with hst
  ¬∑ exact prod_compRel_prod_of_disjoint hst
  ¬∑ exact prod_compRel_prod_of_inter_nonempty <| not_disjoint_iff_nonempty_inter.1 hst

lemma compRel_iUnion (s : Set (X √ó X)) (t : Œπ ‚Üí Set (X √ó X)) : s ‚óã ‚ãÉ i, t i = ‚ãÉ i, s ‚óã t i := by
  aesop

lemma iUnion_compRel (s : Œπ ‚Üí Set (X √ó X)) (t : Set (X √ó X)) : (‚ãÉ i, s i) ‚óã t = ‚ãÉ i, s i ‚óã t := by
  aesop

lemma compRel_sUnion (s : Set (X √ó X)) (T : Set (Set (X √ó X))) : s ‚óã ‚ãÉ‚ÇÄ T = ‚ãÉ t ‚àà T, s ‚óã t := by
  aesop

lemma sUnion_compRel (S : Set (Set (X √ó X))) (t : Set (X √ó X)) : ‚ãÉ‚ÇÄ S ‚óã t = ‚ãÉ s ‚àà S, s ‚óã t := by
  aesop

end Topology.UniformSpace.Defs

namespace TopologicalSpace.IsTopologicalBasis
variable {X : Type*} [TopologicalSpace X] {B : Set (Set X)} {P : Set X ‚Üí Prop}

@[elab_as_elim]
lemma isOpen_induction (hB : IsTopologicalBasis B) (basis : ‚àÄ b ‚àà B, P b)
    (iUnion : ‚àÄ S, (‚àÄ s ‚àà S, P s) ‚Üí P (‚ãÉ‚ÇÄ S)) {s : Set X} (hs : IsOpen s) : P s := by
  obtain ‚ü®S, hS, rfl‚ü© := hB.open_eq_sUnion hs; exact iUnion _ fun b hb ‚Ü¶ basis _ <| hS hb

end TopologicalSpace.IsTopologicalBasis

open TopologicalSpace

variable {X : Type*} [TopologicalSpace X] {s t : Set (X √ó X)} {s‚ÇÅ s‚ÇÇ t‚ÇÅ t‚ÇÇ : Set X}

lemma IsOpen.compRel (hs : IsOpen s) (ht : IsOpen t) : IsOpen (s ‚óã t) := by
  classical
  refine (isTopologicalBasis_opens.prod isTopologicalBasis_opens).isOpen_induction
    ((isTopologicalBasis_opens.prod isTopologicalBasis_opens).isOpen_induction ?_ ?_ ht) ?_ hs
  ¬∑ rintro S hS
    rw [sUnion_compRel]
    exact isOpen_biUnion hS
  ¬∑ rintro _ ‚ü®t‚ÇÅ, ht‚ÇÅ, t‚ÇÇ, ht‚ÇÇ, rfl‚ü© _ ‚ü®s‚ÇÅ, hs‚ÇÅ, s‚ÇÇ, hs‚ÇÇ, rfl‚ü©
    rw [prod_compRel_prod]
    split_ifs
    exacts [isOpen_empty, hs‚ÇÅ.prod ht‚ÇÇ]
  ¬∑ rintro T hT b hb
    rw [compRel_sUnion]
    exact isOpen_biUnion fun t ht ‚Ü¶ hT t ht b hb

I am really surprised we don't have isOpen_induction in mathlib, given how much Patrick likes to hammer home the fact that induction principles are THE important part of any universal property, and a topological basis is one such
Because topological bases are bad.
Because really open sets are bad, and neighborhoods are good x)
That looks great! Unfortunately I think I still need the closed version. If you think this is false, I can share some more context.
That's certainly an argument, yes!
(I'm exagerating purposefully)

Here's another possible proof: the projections from products are open, and S‚àòT=œÄ13(S√óX‚à©X√óT‚Äæ)S\circ T = \pi_{13}(S\times X \cap X\times\overline{T})S‚àòT=œÄ13‚Äã(S√óX‚à©X√óT) where T‚Äæ\overline{T}T is the symmetric of TTT.
I guess this is the same proof, with the open induction pushed into the existing API
Yes
Although you will see that docs#isOpenMap_fst is proven not using opens but using neighborhoods!

Here's a counterexample to the closed claim: Take s=t={(x,y)‚ààR‚â•0√óR‚â•0‚à£1‚â§xy}s = t = \{(x, y) \in \R_{\ge 0} \times \R_{\ge 0} | 1 \le xy\}s=t={(x,y)‚ààR‚â•0‚Äã√óR‚â•0‚Äã‚à£1‚â§xy} Then s‚àòt={(x,z)‚à£‚àÉy,1‚â§xy,yz}=R>0√óR>0s \circ t = \{(x, z) | \exists y, 1 \le xy, yz\} = \R_{> 0} \times \R_{> 0}s‚àòt={(x,z)‚à£‚àÉy,1‚â§xy,yz}=R>0‚Äã√óR>0‚Äã
ok let's see which part of the hypotheses of what I'm working on rules out that counterexample
#24173
I think I can avoid the closed lemma
Avoiding false lemmas is always a good thing! :grinning_face_with_smiling_eyes:

Now I need

import Mathlib

proof_wanted IsSymmetricRel.compRel_comm {Œ± : Type*} {s t : Set (Œ± √ó Œ±)}
    (hs : IsSymmetricRel s) (ht : IsSymmetricRel t) : compRel s t = compRel t s

proof_wanted IsSymmetricRel.compRel {Œ± : Type*} {s t : Set (Œ± √ó Œ±)}
    (hs : IsSymmetricRel s) (ht : IsSymmetricRel t) : IsSymmetricRel (compRel s t)

I hope these are true as well
(should this be in another thread?)
I proved the last one already. The first one is a consequence
That's weird, because I changed my proof to not require these after finding what I thought was a counterexample
Oh sorry, it's only true under s = t. That's what I proved
